name: collaterally
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
in a way that is connected to something else, but less important or central than it: Such a judgement may be attacked at any time, either directly or collaterally. A judgment, order, or decree may be challenged collaterally if it was obtained by fraud.
More examplesFewer examplesThere is always someone who will be collaterally affected by changes like this.The court’s records are presumed accurate and cannot be collaterally impeached.Any employee who doesn't punish the offenders or report them to the authorities may be considered collaterally responsible.
